body: @nishantmonu51 please don't rebase the whole branch, it breaks previous review conversations and makes it harder to track changes, merge master into your feature branch instead.
@jihoonson Thoughts on backporting this to 0.12?

Thanks for this fix. We ran into the same issue about the same time this fix got posted. Since that time our clusters kept crashing due to full HDFS disks.
Took me a long time to investigate and finally find this PR.

I'd suggest to not even use log level INFO for logging such large text fragments.
The changed code still contains the following lines:
+    // Note: log is splitted into two lines so that a new String is not generated to print it.
+    // segmentsStr could be quite large when re-indexing multiple months of data.
+    logger.info("Segment to read are...");
+    logger.info(segmentsStr);

To my understanding, this still emits the large volumes of log-text. How about using DEBUG or TRACE level logging for the segmentsStr ?

thanks
Sascha
+cc @gianm for thoughts.

@leventov: Added comments to expression selectors and changed the formatting as mentioned. 
Also created follow up issues for your comments that need not block this PR. 

Could you also add a summarized comment regarding following - 
Have you completed the review and were above comments were your final set of comments ? 
are there any major changes apart from the nitpicks that you think are needed before this can be merged ? 
Any thoughts on, How long do you think this PR is going to take to be ready to be merged in your opinion ?

The main reason I did this was because some selectors wrap expression selectors and prefer an `ExprEval` object so they can get object casting behavior (`asDouble`, `asString`, etc). If we have some standard functions for casting `Object` to various Druid types then I think the ExprEval selectors aren't needed, and we can go with the first solution: "ExpressionSelectors.makeExprEvalSelector() should return ColumnValueSelector, not of ExprEval"

Btw, there is no incoherency that I'm aware of in the current code. It is just confusing since there are both ExprEval selectors and normal value Object selectors, and callers have to use the right one.
@leventov thanks for review- updated the patch.

Thanks for your thoughts @gianm. Will refactor things accordingly in a follow up PR. 
the incoherancy in comment here is for the newly added isNull method, which returns false for ObjectSelectors instead of computing the object and determine its nullability for performance reasons.

@kevinconaway basically, I think we don't have to backport this to 0.12 because this is a new feature rather than improving an existing one. However, I think it would be fine if this doesn't cause a lot of conflicts for backporting. More people can test this new task type earlier instead of waiting for a next release or backporting this by themselves. @gianm @jon-wei what do you think?

> basically, I think we don't have to backport this to 0.12 because this is a new feature rather than improving an existing one.

The reason I ask is that I'd like to get off our fork and start using this feature when 0.12 is released, rather than waiting for 0.13
@leventov Could you have another look please?

@kevinconaway I'm sorry to say, but we usually backports only bug fixes, so I would say it's difficult to make an exception for this PR without a reasonable reason. We already created 0.12.0-rc3 (https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-development/DZx-opThc50) which will be released soon unless another bug is found.
No worries, thanks for following up

I've been testing several ways to support Hadoop 2.7 line. From my testings so far, I think the easiest way is to provide our own `hadoop-aws.jar` which shades some libraries like `aws-java-sdk` and `jackson-datatype-guava`. I verified hadoop indexing works with Hadoop 2.7.5 with the customized `hadoop-aws.jar`.

This library is needed only for Hadoop 2.7 line. The official `hadoop-aws.jar` can be used for Hadoop 2.9 and 3.0. @b-slim @gianm @drcrallen what do you think?
I am ok with this solution in principle. How would we do it though?
@dclim We're not using Tranquility.  I don't know Scala well enough to confidently hack on it.  The last time I looked at it, it wasn't up to date with even Druid 0.10 but that was some time ago

My opinion is that Hadoop 2.9.0 was only released in Nov 2017 so it's too new to make the minimum version. People don't tend to update their Hadoop clusters very often.

> I am ok with this solution in principle. How would we do it though?

@gianm We may fork the `hadoop-aws` module as a project under `druid-io`, and make some changes to support hadoop 2.7 line. And we may release the customized `hadoop-aws.jar` along with our next release (0.13). Does it make sense?

> This is order 5% slow down for the bad case. Can when the good vs bad cases would be encountered be expanded more?

Sure. ValueMatchers are for so-called "post filtering" which means filtering during a row scan, rather than using the index.

Imagine a filter like `WHERE col1 = 'foo' AND col2 LIKE '%bar%'` where col1 and col2 are both unindexed (so we need to do ValueMatcher filtering for both). The good case is where within the set of rows where col1 is 'foo', you don't see the entire constellation of possible col2 values. It means lazy matching saves a lot of time. The good case should be very common for multi-tenant type datasets (imagine `WHERE customer_id = '123' AND product_id = '456'` if products are unique to customers).

The bad case is where this does not happen: where there is no pruning of col2 values based on a col1 filter. In this case, laziness doesn't save any time.

Some more context on this change is: today Druid uses indexes very aggressively, so string post filtering doesn't happen very often. I think it actually may never happen on QueryableIndex, since between QueryableIndexStorageAdapter (which uses bitmaps for any top-level filters that support them) and OrFilter/AndFilter (which have makeMatcher impls that use bitmaps when possible for subfilters) it looks like it may never get called. So today, I think this change really just affects IncrementalIndex filtering.

The motivation behind this change is to open up future optimizations like:

- Combined with the feature in #5402, make it more feasible to load big unique string values (like free form text) without wasting space and also wasting time on eager filtering when those columns are filtered on (it is very likely they will end up in the "good" case)
- I want to explore optimizations that involve not always blindly using indexes. Consider a filter like `WHERE col1 = '123' AND col2 LIKE '%foo%'` where col1 and col2 both have bitmap indexes. If the filter `col1 = '123'` is very selective then the query will likely be faster if we _avoid_ using the index for `col2 LIKE '%foo%'` (saving the work needed to examine every value and union a bunch of bitmaps) and instead run it as a ValueMatcher based filter.
LGTM after addressing the comments of @nishantmonu51.
@drcrallen would you please answer for my question [here](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2900/files#r155724414)?
@gianm could we make the matcher eager then, if there is just one filter?

> @gianm could we make the matcher eager then, if there is just one filter?

It would make sense, although would be a more substantial refactoring of a lot of layers of interfaces (makeMatcher has to know how which mode to run in). I would rather not do it in this PR. Especially since I don't think it will have an effect on QueryableIndex based queries right now. And even if we do explore using ValueMatchers more, it probably won't be too important then either, since we'd aim to only use them in the good case (if there's just one filter we'd use bitmaps, unless the user disabled bitmaps for that column).
Might be worth creating an issue then.

Will this work with a remote cluster? I thought - usually - the remote cluster prefers its own Hadoop jars rather than any Hadoop jars that user code (i.e. Druid) might ship. I guess it's fine since on the remote cluster, Druid probably won't be using aws-java-sdk directly, so there won't be an opportunity to have problems there?

Another thing that could cause disconnects is https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3393 which will have a fix in 0.12.0 (https://github.com/metamx/java-util/pull/73 was incorporated by way of #5289).
Changed milestone since we did a backport.

I have looked into this and found out that the issue is not really the transactional world (transactions are part of separate topics) but as pointed by @gianm the optional log compaction that can happen to the Kafka log as [per docs](https://kafka.apache.org/documentation/#compaction)  Kafka Brokers can compact record with the same key, therefore Kafka log can have gaps. This option is on by default starting from [Kafka 0.9.1](https://kafka.apache.org/documentation.html#upgrade_901_notable) `log.cleanup.policy=compact`. To close this issue, if needed we can update the docs to make sure Druid users know about the issue and the flag. Also IMO we can remove the warning log msg I don't think it really helps, if the user is asking to allow gaps he doesn't need a warning about that. @pjain1  and @gianm  what you think?
@jihoonson This has been running on our clusters for about 3 weeks, things look much better with this change

`Is java.nio.file.Files.copy a candidate here?`

As a side note, it looks like `java.nio.MappedByteBuffer#fd` holds the file descriptor as well, which is cool. So an madvise approach is an alternative that could work, but would require more Unsafe digging into the byte buffer addresses

What is "in-memory tier"?

Hi @himanshug. I'm working on https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/5428, and thus supposed to modify some logic of `RemoteTaskRunner` and `HttpRemoteTaskRunner`. I got a question while reading the code of `HttpRemoteTaskRunner`. 

At first, I supposed that many parts can be shared `RemoteTaskRunner` between `HttpRemoteTaskRunner`. More specifically, I thought the only difference between them will be how they can send/receive events (via ZooKeeper or HTTP). However, it turns out that they don't share code paths. So, I wonder there is any difference between how they work. If so, would you let me know what are differences and why those differences are needed?

@leventov sorry took `in-memory-tier` word for granted :) . `in-memory tier` : tier of historicals where all the segments in a server can be kept to physical memory assuming as long as historical has about druid-process-memory + loaded_segment_size or more worth of ram.
In our setup `druid.server.maxSize=100G` and total memory available it around 140G.
Maybe it's better to modify `TaskQueue` instead of modifying `RemoteTaskRunner`s, but I'm still curious.

@bolkedebruin am not sure how much you are familiar with dependency injection used by Druid. One way to do this is to add boolean config variable maybe call it `useNativeIO` perhaps you can shoved it in `io.druid.query.DruidProcessingConfig`, then you would have to get an instance of the `DruidProcessingConfig` and using that flag you add an if true/false useNative/useOldCode. Please let me know if you need more help with this. Usually, we prefer with testing the new stuff before turning it on by default. Thanks
Failed from https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2373

Big feature for us that isn't mentioned here yet is the new `parseBatch` API in `InputRowParser`.
This change allows an `InputRowParser` to emit multiple rows per message.

We are making use of this to eliminate a transformation that needed to happen prior to Druid ingestion. It also means that we can do reingestion from our raw input data without needing to have stored transformed intermediates for Druid to consume.
Big simplification of our data architecture and could prove useful for others that have input data that isn't sufficiently denormalised/flattened for direct ingestion.

Same for us Joseph

1. additional to task context, would be nice to support this via overlord config. would make configuration easy.
2. i am assuming after this change a transition of status from running -> failed -> running will be valid. Need to have way for user to know for a task with status failed, whether its going to be retried or not. 
3. IMO this is a useful as a generic feature for all task types, not only batch ingestion. E.g same retry concept can be applied to Merge/Append/Kill/Compaction tasks too.

@b-slim (@drcrallen) Thanks for the pointers but I see some challenges. Where do you want me to check for the configuration? Ie. in the NativeIO class or in its calling classes? Reading  https://github.com/google/guice/wiki/Injections#static-injections it seems that it needs to be done from calling classes which would be quite the refactor (anything that uses CompressionUtils needs to pass a flag that turns NativeIO on or off).

Are there smarter ways?

@AlexanderSaydakov also please when addressing comments, answer to each of them, to make it easier to track.

Also please address @b-slim's comments.
